entity.name: Thoth - God of Wisdom & Writing
entity.subtitle: God of Wisdom, Writing, Magic, and the Moon
entity.description: Thoth is the ibis-headed god of knowledge, writing, science, and magic. As the divine scribe, he records the judgment of souls and maintains the cosmic order. Master of hieroglyphs and sacred wisdom, Thoth embodies the intellectual and magical power of the written word and serves as mediator, messenger, and keeper of divine secrets.

attributes.Titles: Lord of Divine Words, Scribe of Ma'at, Reckoner of Time, He Who Balances, Master of Knowledge, Moon God, Three Times Great (Thoth Trismegistus in Hellenistic period)
attributes.Domains: Writing, wisdom, magic, science, mathematics, astronomy, medicine, judgment, arbitration, the moon, time, languages, knowledge
attributes.Symbols: Ibis bird, baboon, writing palette and reed pen, papyrus scroll, lunar disk and crescent, ankh, was scepter, scales
attributes.Sacred Animals: Ibis (represents wisdom, curved beak like crescent moon), baboon (sacred to the moon, intelligent)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Papyrus (writing material), palm fronds (used in time reckoning)

mythology_stories.intro: Thoth's mythology emphasizes his role as mediator, healer, and keeper of sacred knowledge. He serves the gods through wisdom rather than force, resolving conflicts through words and magic.

key_myths.name: Invention of Writing
key_myths.description: Thoth created hieroglyphs, the sacred writing of the gods. He presented this gift to humanity through the pharaohs, enabling the recording of history, magic spells, and divine wisdom. The Egyptians called hieroglyphs "medu netjer" (words of the gods), believing them to possess inherent magical power.

key_myths.name: Healing the Eye ofHorus
key_myths.description: Healing the Eye of Horus: During the battle between Horus and Set, Set tore out Horus's eye. Thoth restored it through magic and mathematics, making it whole again. The restored Eye of Horus (Wedjat) became a symbol of healing, wholeness, and protection. This myth established Thoth as patron of medicine and healing arts.

key_myths.name: Arbitrator BetweenHorusandSet
key_myths.description: Arbitrator Between Horus and Set: Thoth served as mediator in the divine tribunal judging between Horus and Set for rulership of Egypt. His wisdom and impartiality helped resolve the conflict, advocating for justice and rightful succession. His role as arbitrator established him as god of law and fair judgment.

key_myths.name: Scribe of the Judgment
key_myths.description: In the Hall of Two Truths, while Anubis weighs hearts against the feather of Ma'at, Thoth records the results. His perfect record-keeping ensures cosmic justice. He announces whether souls are "justified" and may enter the afterlife, or must be devoured by Ammit.

key_myths.name: The Gambling with the Moon
key_myths.description: When Nut (sky goddess) was cursed by Ra not to give birth on any day of the year, Thoth gambled with the moon god Khonsu and won 1/72nd of the moon's light from each day. With this light, he created five extra days (epagomenal days) outside the regular 360-day calendar, allowing Nut to give birth to Osiris, Isis, Set, Nephthys, and Horus the Elder.

key_myths.name: Partner in Mummification
key_myths.description: Thoth spoke the magical spells necessary for successful mummification and resurrection. His words of power, recorded in funerary texts, gave the dead power to navigate the underworld and transform into akh (effective spirits).

mythology_stories.sources: Pyramid Texts,Coffin Texts,Book of the Dead,Papyrus of Ani, Temple inscriptions at Hermopolis, Contendings ofHorusandSet, Medical papyri (Ebers Papyrus, Edwin Smith Papyrus)

relationships.allies: Ra(serves as scribe and advisor),Ma'at(partner injustice),Osiris(records judgment for),Isis(fellow practitioner of magic),Horus(healed and supported)
relationships.enemies: None specifically;Thothopposes chaos and falsehood through wisdom rather than combat. OpposesApepas part ofRa'screw but through magic rather than force.

family.parents: Self-created or born from the head ofSet(depending on tradition); sometimes described as born fromRa'sheart
family.consorts: Ma'at(goddess oftruthandjustice), Seshat (goddess of writing and measurement), Nehemetawy

worship.sacred sites: Thoth's primary cult center was Hermopolis Magna (Khmun, "City of Eight") in Middle Egypt, where he was worshipped as creator god and leader of the Ogdoad (eight primordial deities). Sacred baboons and ibises were kept, mummified, and buried in catacombs at Tuna el-Gebel near Hermopolis. He was also venerated at Abydos, Memphis, and throughout Egypt in temples where scribes worked.
worship.festivals:
• Festival of Thoth: Celebrated on the first month (Thoth) of the Egyptian calendar year. Involved offerings to ensure accurate record-keeping and maintenance of cosmic order for the coming year.
  • Epagomenal Days: The five extra days Thoth won from the moon were celebrated as birthdays of the gods, with Thoth honored as the clever deity who made them possible.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Thoth included: papyrus scrolls, writing implements, incense (frankincense), white linen, ibis feathers, offerings of baboon or ibis (symbolic or actual mummies), wine, milk, bread. Scribes made offerings before beginning important writings, asking for Thoth's guidance to write accurately and powerfully.
worship.prayers & invocations: Scribes invoked: "Thoth, Lord of Divine Words, guide my hand. Grant me skill in writing, clarity in thought, power in my words. Make my hieroglyphs perfect, my calculations true. As you recorded the judgment of the gods, so make my records accurate and enduring." Students prayed: "Thoth, open my mind to wisdom. Grant me understanding of sacred knowledge. Make me swift in learning, retentive in memory, skilled in all arts. As you are master of all sciences, make me worthy to learn your secrets." Magicians called upon Thoth's power in spells, as his words carried divine authority and creative force.
